message.content:
We need to “extract” the cost items that later become “cost of sales” on the income statement. In many accounting systems the cost of goods sold is “posted” on each sale using a cost‐amount field (instead of later “matching out” purchases to cost of sales). In our input table almost all of the “Sale” rows show a (generated) cost value (in the “cost_amount” column). (Other kinds of rows – “Purchase,” “Expense,” “Depreciation,” etc – feed other parts of the income statement; here “Total Cost,” as used in this task, is understood to mean the sum of the cost of sold items.)

For example, the very first sale row (id “Sale20240102001”) shows a cost_amount of 20,000.00; the next sale row (id “Sale20240104004”) shows 20,000.00, and so on. (All other “Sale” rows provide a cost_amount value.) 

Thus, to compute the “total cost” we add up the cost_amount across all sale transactions. (All other transaction types are “book‐entries” that do not affect the cost of sales figure.)

Step‐by‐step, the sale rows (in order of appearance) and their cost_amount values are as follows:

  1. Sale20240102001:  20,000.00  
  2. Sale20240104004:  20,000.00  
  3. Sale20240105005:  1,000.00  
  4. Sale20240105006:  20,000.00  
  5. Sale20240106009:  100,000.00  
  6. Sale20240107010:  20,000.00  
  7. Sale20240107011:  100,000.00  
  8. Sale20240107012:  20,000.00  
  9. Sale20240108015:  100,000.00  
  10. Sale20240108016:  1,000.00  
  11. Sale20240108017:  20,000.00  
  12. Sale20240109019:  100,000.00  
  13. Sale20240109020:  5,000.00  
  14. Sale20240109021:  5,000.00  
  15. Sale20240112024:  100,000.00  
  16. Sale20240112025:  1,000.00  
  17. Sale20240112026:  100,000.00  
  18. Sale20240114029:  20,000.00  
  19. Sale20240114030:  100,000.00  
  20. Sale20240114031:  20,000.00  
  21. Sale20240115032:  1,000.00  
  22. Sale20240117036:  1,000.00  
  23. Sale20240117037:  5,000.00  
  24. Sale20240117038:  1,000.00  
  25. Sale20240118041:  100,000.00  
  26. Sale20240120043:  5,000.00  
  27. Sale20240120044:  20,000.00  
  28. Sale20240120045:  1,000.00  
  29. Sale20240121047:  20,000.00  
  30. Sale20240121048:  100,000.00  
  31. Sale20240121049:  5,000.00  
  32. Sale20240122050:  5,000.00  
  33. Sale20240122051:  20,000.00  
  34. Sale20240123053:  100,000.00  
  35. Sale20240125056:  5,000.00  
  36. Sale20240125057:  20,000.00  
  37. Sale20240125058:  100,000.00  
  38. Sale20240127060:  1,000.00  
  39. Sale20240127061:  20,000.00  
  40. Sale20240130063:  100,000.00  
  41. Sale20240130064:  5,000.00  
  42. Sale20240130065:  20,000.00  
  43. Sale20240131068:  20,000.00  
  44. Sale20240131069:  5,000.00  
  45. Sale20240201071:  20,000.00  
  46. Sale20240201072:  5,000.00  
  47. Sale20240202073:  100,000.00  
  48. Sale20240202074:  20,000.00  
  49. Sale20240203075:  100,000.00  
  50. Sale20240205076:  100,000.00  
  51. Sale20240205077:  20,000.00  
  52. Sale20240205078:  100,000.00  

When these 52 amounts are summed the running total comes to 2,018,000.00.

That is, the final “total cost” in the income statement is 2,018,000.00.

Thus the answer is:

{"solution": {"Total Cost": "2018000.00"}}
